WINNIPEG, May 22.
There was a very small attendance at the meeting of the House of Commons today. After routine matters were disposed of, the distribution of a new province was proposed in the shape of a clause to lower duties on the iron manufacturers. Several alterations relating to drygoods were discussed. Mr. Nelson introduced a motion to give free trade to the Government to deal with it, but his brother has not yet stated how the bills may be altered.

The Other Representative at Ottawa is just now doing some very important work.

The BUDGET-INCOME.

Poveshell and Poveshell are oilier and uaderstanding attractive, but they have an especial charm when, on balancing up your bank account, you find that your cheapest good for ten years has become a favorite dish. Disallowed in form! What we want is production and encouragement to capitalists, and fewer charters granted to pious railway companies.

The fears expressed by some that the continuance of the policy of disallowance will prevent铁路的conservation to the Northwest originate more from political chicanery than anything else. Every inch of new territory has been used up in the disallowance in form! What we want is production and encouragement to capitalists, and fewer charters granted to pious railway companies.

The importance of overseas generally are in every case bringing our efforts as near as practicable to a level with that of the United States. Mr. Mike Fearnley, the National Policy Secretary, cannot object to this, and as remarked by Sir Charles Tupper, "capitalists would not come with large Canadian enterprises without fear of any disturbance by a change of administration."

Sir James McCallum (Liberal) "too often supports his views abroad in the North-West Liberals say to this, he does not find himself favored in the Old Country; but neither did the first installment of the National Policy. If we are to continue the policy of our neighbors until the British government gave its consent to the taxing of British warships by the Canadian Parliament," we should agree with Sir James Macdonald.

SPEAKING OF Sir Charles Tupper's budget speech the Globe of May 18th says: "There was a general feeling that Sir Charles Tupper, this afternoon, was able and, in some respects, admirable performer. There was a generous spirit for legitimate national conclusions and an absence of partisan demarcation which put the whole subject justly into the hands of the House, and lifted the discussion above the mean level of party warfare. And yet the whole speech was full of craft, alive with words and framed at every point to put the Government's case in the strongest light possible."

There was a manifest failure of conviction in the policies which the House had reason to expect. There was no attempt to deal with the manifold difficulties which it must have known will warrant. There was a manifestation of supreme concern for the interests of Canada but utterly regardless, and do not regard at the best evidence of devotion to Canada. Those few defects which were apparent in the deliverer of the model of discovery, and a very complete presentation of a case to the merits of whom there will be none but justice. But however highly thought of that minister can be no serious question." Mr. Macdonald, who refused to treat with a single member of the official opposition, spoke at great length upon the advantages for the interests of the Empire seeing that Canada is a part of it. Even this, however, would have been enough to have at heart the best interests of the Empire. Many, again, be disposed to deny the self-reliance which pervaded the late budget speeches, Sir Charles Tupper's speech was characterized by a general regard for legitimate mathematical conclusions, and a very complete presentation of a case to the merits of whom there will be none but justice.

Mr. Brown, another colonial of the same stamp and speaking of the same subject, with all allowances made for him, said there could be no member of the Liberal party suffer."

In reply to the question as to what the Government's policy was to do to allow malcontents to have their play, Mr. Macdonald replied as follows: - "The policy of the Government has not been changed. Our policy is the same as that before the election. We have made an agreement with the C. P. R. Company, and we are bound in honor, to every Canadian, to observe such agreement. Some will say that in certain provinces, where there is a large surplus, we should take such lands in the same way that it does in regard to the Northwest. The principal portion of the contract has been entered into in the Northwest. It was designed to ensure the export trade. Now, we have agreed to some terms, but nothing has been done so far as the terms made with the individual companies, as far as the terms between the individuals and the Company.

MOORE & MACDOWALL.
QUEEN'S BIRTHDAY.

The 24th of May passed off very quietly in the Royal City, the only excitement being centred in a cricket match between two teams composed of Honorary Police and members of the Prince Albert Club. The day was all that could be desired except that it was considered just a little dry. Two outdoor picnics were held in the country, one in the hollow flat and the other at Red Deer Hill, at which both young and old were present. It must not be inferred, however, from the composition of the parties that there was celebrated that the people of this town and surrounding country are any less enthusiastic about the Queen in the broad Dominion, the true reason of the apparent lack of enthusiasm being that the citizens have been loyalists until the end of July, when the Queen's Jubilee and Dominion Day will be celebrated in a variety of ways by such independent spirits as the citizens of Great Britain and the Dominion of Canada. Thus there will be no lack of the usual spirit which will make up for the shortcomings of the weather. With obstinacy they tread River street and draw their wind and sunshine without reservation. But we will not give the programme that day later on.

Early in the morning of the 24th flags were flapping to the breeze from the various flagstaffs in the town, as also the flagstaffs on the two sides of the grounds immediately east of the Mission schoolhouse. Tents were also erected on the grounds near the club. Sharp at ten o'clock the cricket match commenced. The Folk Club took the field to go to the wickets, retiring with a score of 77. The batting on the part of Mr. Macdonald, Sheppard, Parker and Sheppard was excellent, and the bowling of Mr. Red was very destructive, he having taken six wickets in eleven overs. The Folk Club then came out to take the wickets retiring with a score of 84. To this score Hannan contributed 27, Mr. Wilson 15, Mr. Macdonald 13, Sheppard 12, and Sheppard 10. The bowling on the part of the police was not as good as that of their opponents, though. Hannan and Wilson were dismissed in six overs with a score of 30. At the conclusion of the first innings the clubs adjourned to the Prince Albert Hotel. After lunch the play was resumed, but whether from the fact that partook of too much refreshment or from the fact that the second part of the game was nearly so well contested as the first, the Folk Club again took the field retiring with a score of 63, to which Mr. Hannan and Sheppard contributed 10 and 13 respectively. In the innings of Folk Club a score of 21 and Parker three wickets in four overs, to a score of 77. Taken the new total stands Folk Club 84, Hannan 81, the latter having to none 40 to win, which they accomplished with greater ease than the other party. Hannan's score was 35, the largest score of the day; D. Peterson 4, and Mr. C. Baker 9, not much, though the latter had some wickets to spare. Altogether the playing was very creditable to both clubs, and the spectators showed that they had to practice. The game was witnessed by a number of ladies and gentlemen in every part of the grounds. The ladies had given the usual cheer for one another, and they adjourned to the residence of Mr. Wilson, where during the day they—they were treated to the best that gentleman had at his disposal.

LOCAL NEWS.

Rev. Mother Austin of St. Anne's Convent, died at six o'clock on Thursday evening. The deceased lady was one of the oldest members of the Order of Prince Albert, and was highly educated and much esteemed. The funeral service will be conducted by Rev. Father O'Connell at the church at 10 A.M. A public funeral service will take place in St. Anne's Church on Tuesday, May 7th of this week. We shall give a sketch of this next week.

A large number of Metis came to town for the grain from the South Branch during the last few days. It appears that the reason they did not apply for the land grant was because they thought they had been led to believe that if they gave them on their farms and the crops would grow, they would be able to get other lands from them. Sept. Perry learning this immediately wired Mr. Macdonald, who wired back that he thought it was that the Government would not deal fairlyly with them, but that the time was not ripe for such action. They must wait until such time as they were able to do so. This being satisfactory, the Metis immediately wired Mr. Macdonald that they secured the seed they required.

The many friends of Mr. George Dack, late Dominion Land Agent at this place, will be interested to hear that his death took place in the Winnipeg Hospital on the afternoon of the 11th inst. Mr. Dack had been ill for several weeks since 1873, and was widely known and respected of. He was first in the employ of the Hudson Bay Company, and before that in the Dominion Lands office. He was a member of the Scrip Commission last year, and died in the hospital ward of this year also. The cause of his death was a cold contracted while on a visit to his home in England. It was believed that he was forced to return to Winnipeg and proceed to the hospital, where, although he appeared to be recovering, he died in the course of an hour. His remains have been sent to his old home, where he will be buried, for interment.

EDMONTON

From the Bulletin, April 30.

Some Indians left for Battleford on Friday.

Work will be commenced shortly on the completion of the Calgary trail, extending at Edmonton to the North West Government account. Fraser & Co. has the contract for the construction of the road, which is to be eight feet wide, twenty feet long, and a half high, on the H. R. reserve, for Dr. McKay, chief trader for the H. R. Reserve, and Mr. Wilson, Mrs. McKay will come to reside in Edmonton. For the purpose of purchasing goods for the reserve, Mr. Wilson will take a route via Lake Athabasca, taking an outfit of goods purchased from Norris & Carey, Edmonton. Mr. Wilson will travel the river country from Qu'Appelle, in British Columbia, and is sending a large outfit of goods to the reserve. Mr. Wilson will take an experimental trip by way of Edmonton this fall, when, if he finds this route preferable, as it no doubt is, he will adopt it in future.

J. Kelly has 3,000 saw logs out for cutting this summer.

W. S. Robson has been appointed deputy sheriff and A. Taylor deputy clerk of the court.
